questions.text: Which of the following is the most powerful example of social cohesion in social organisation?
questions.solution:
The most powerful example of social cohesion in social organization is the family.

It is the most basic and primary unit in all societies.

questions.text: Which of the following is an unstable and emotional temporary social group with a leader?
questions.solution:
A mob is an unstable and emotional temporary social group with a leader.

Temporary social groups can be classified into:

  • Crowd- It is a temporary group motivated by a common interest or curiosity. It lacks an internal organization and has no leader.
  • Mob- It is a crowd with a leader, and is more emotional than a crowd. It is unstable and has no internal organization.
  • Herd- This social group has a leader and the members have to follow his/her orders without question.

A band is a permanent spatial group that constitutes a few families living together. Other permanent spatial groups are villages, cities, towns and the state.

questions.text: What is the correct order of a family cycle?

choices.text: Formation, extension, complete extension, dissolution, contraction, complete contraction
Formation,contraction,extension, complete extension, dissolution, complete dissolution
Formation, contraction, complete contraction, extension, complete extension, dissolution
Formation, extension, complete extension, contraction, complete contraction, dissolution

questions.solution:
The order of the family cycle is formation, extension, complete extension, contraction, complete contraction and dissolution.

questions.text: In urbanized and industrialized countries, occupation is a major determinant of all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Occupation is not a determinant of community participation.

Occupation in most urbanized and industrialized communities is a major determinant of:

  • Economic rewards
  • Extent of authority
  • Extent of obligations
  • Degree of status
  • Values and lifestyles

questions.text: Which of the following is not a limitation of classifying social class according to occupation?

choices.text: Inequality between men and women in same jobs

questions.solution:
Most classifications of social class based on occupational take skills into consideration.

Occupation is a useful measure of social differentiation particularly in communities highly industrialised and urbanized.

Limitations of cccupational classification of social class:

  • Heterogenous grouping- occupations grouped together are not usually related to each other
  • Occupational mobility- occupations practiced by the members of a social class as well as the perception of a certain occupation in the hierarchy may change over a period of time
  • Gender biases- the same occupation may be considered as belonging to a superior class for men as compared to women

questions.text: You are tasked with conducting a health and wellness survey of the employees of your hospital. Which of the following scales will you not use to classify their socio-economic statuses?
questions.solution:
Likert scale is not a scale used for socio-economic status (SES). It is a psychometric scale used to understand the attitude of people from their responses. It is a scale widely used in questionnaire-based research.

Scales that have been used for SES are:

  • Udai Pareek scale
  • Kuppuswamy scale
  • Radhukar scale
  • Jalota scale
  • Shirvastava scale
  • Bharadwaj scale
  • Kulshestra scale
  • Hollingshead scale.

Related Pearl: Socio-Economic Status and the modified Kuppuswamy’s Socio-economic Status Scale, 2017

Socio-Economic Status:

  • The socio-economic status (SES) is a person’s position in the societal hierarchy, which in turn is an important determinant of health.
  • SES may be inherited but in most situations, it is achieved on the basis of occupation, income, type of housing, neighbourhood, material possessions, etc.
  • Many composite scales have been developed to classify SES. Some of them are listed below:

Scale

Used for:

BG Prasad scale

Urban and rural areas

Kuppuswamy scale

Urban and peri-urban areas

Uday Pareek

Rural areas

Some other scales that have been used are Radhukar scale, Jalota scale, Shirvastava scale, Bharadwaj scale, Kulshestra scale and the Hollingshead scale.

 

The Kuppuswamy scale:

The Kuppuswamy scale was designed to classify the socio-economic status in urban and peri-urban areas.

It was devised in 1976 by Kuppuswamy and was later modified to be called the Modified Kuppuswamy Scale.

This scale uses the following components:

  • Education of head of the family
  • Occupation of the head of the family
  • Monthly income of the family

Each indicator is given a score and the final score from 3–29 reveals the Socio-Economic Score and class of the person.

The scale requires regular upgrades owing to the changing value of the currency and for this, the changes are based on the Consumer Price Index for industrial workers (CPI IW) with the year 2001 as the base year.

questions.text: In the doctor-patient relationship, which of the following is not a level of communication?
questions.solution:
Communication on a psychological plane is not a level of communication in a doctor-patient relationship.

For a successful doctor-patient relationship, a doctor must have in his/her regard communication on the following levels:

  • Communication on an emotional plane: To build rapport, ensure openness and incite trust from the patient.
  • Communication on a cultural plane: To understand the community to which the patient belongs, his/her cultural factors that may influence health and disease and also for economic understanding of the patient.
  • Communication on an intellectual plane: To give adequate explanation for their conditions and help the patients develop insight into their ailments.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best suited role for a medical social worker?

choices.text: Designing coping strategies, interviewing and case work

questions.solution:
A medical social worker is a person who is trained mainly in social work and interviewing.

He/she carries out duties that augment public and community healthcare by way of identifying, understanding and relaying important information about a patient’s determinants of health.

They are not involved in active treatment, prescribing or providing economic support.

questions.text: Which of the following practices is covered under the COPRA act?
questions.solution:
Consumer Protection Act or COPRA was instituted in 1986 and deals with consumer rights.

It recognizes six rights of the consumers, which are:

  • Right to safety
  • Right to be informed
  • Right to be heard
  • Right to choose
  • Right to seek redressal
  • Right to consumer education

questions.text: Which of the following is used to describe an interview used to note the gradual influence of some social or psychological process?
questions.solution:
A repetitive interview is used to note the gradual influence of some social or psychological process. A record is maintained to understand the changes.

Interviews are methods used widely in investigations and in research. A proper interview technique must be employed to achieve the objective.

Aims of an interview:

  • To secure information usually through face to face association and to understand the individual/group being interviewed.
  • To form a hypothesis.
  • To collect personal data for quantitative purposes.
  • To collect data from secondary sources of information.

Types of interviews:

  • A direct or structured interview consists of predetermined questions and sequence.
  • A non-directive or unstructured interview doesn’t have any sequence of questions set beforehand. The interviewer listens and allows the speaker to narrate his/her own experiences or opinions.
  • A focused interview is usually used to study effects of mass communication like radio broadcasts or film. In this, the interviewer/researcher focuses on a particular aspect on the problem and draws responses from people.
  • A repetitive interview is used to note the gradual influence of some social or psychological process. A record is maintained to understand the changes.

questions.text: Arrange the following steps of an interview in the correct order in a sequence.

choices.text: Starting an interview, making a report, establishing contact, securing rapport
Establishing contact, making a report, starting an interview, securing rapport
Establishing contact, starting an interview, securing rapport, making a report
Starting an interview, securing rapport, making a report, establishing contact

questions.solution:
The correct sequence of steps of interviewing are establishing contact, starting an interview, securing rapport, making a report.

Technique of interviewing involves:

  1. Establishing contact
  2. Starting an interview
  3. Securing rapport
  4. Recall
  5. Probe questions
  6. Encouragement
  7. Guiding the interview
  8. Recording
  9. Closing the interview
  10. Report

questions.text: What is the application of scientific methods to investigate the study of complex human organizations, services and management called?
questions.solution:
Operational research is the application of scientific methods of investigation to study complex human organizations, services and management.

Pure research is also called fundamental research or basic research. It is aimed at improving scientific theories or understanding of them.

Applied research is a methodology used for a specific, practical problem like diseases or business. It involves the practical application of science.

questions.text: What was the purpose of setting up the Nirbhaya Fund?

choices.text: Providing free medical care for women

questions.solution: The Nirbhaya Fund was set up by the government of India for promoting the safety of women.

questions.text: Choose the correct match.

choices.text: Gross Domestic Product- gross income generated only from within the country
Gross National Product- gross domestic product minus the depreciation on a country’s capital goods
Net National Product- income generated from within the country and income received from abroad
Net Domestic Product- market value of all final goods and services in a country during a year after allowing for depreciation

questions.solution:
Gross Domestic Product (GDP) is the income generated only from within the country and does not include income received from abroad.

Related Pearl: Economics

  • Gross National Income (GNI):
    • It is also known as the gross national product (GNP). It is the gross income generated from within the country as well as the income received from abroad. It is expressed as either ‘at current prices’ or ‘at constant prices’.
  • Per capita income:
    • It is arrived at by dividing the GNP by the total population of a country. It is a general indicator of national wealth.
  • Gross Domestic Product (GDP):
    • It is the gross income generated only from within the country. It doesn’t include income from abroad.
  • Net National Product (NNP):
    • It is the market value of all final goods and services in a country during a year after depreciation has been allowed for.
  • Net Domestic Product (NDP):
    • It is gross domestic product (GDP) minus the depreciation of a country’s capital goods.
  • Purchasing Power Parity (PPP):
    • It is an economic theory that compares the currencies of different countries through a market basket of goods approach. According to this concept, two currencies are in equilibrium when a market basket of goods is priced the same in both countries.

questions.text: What percentage of GDP was spent on public health in 2020?
questions.solution:
The total public health expenditure is around 1.25% percentage of India's GDP (National Health Profile 2020 report).

The National Health Policy, 2017 states the aim to increase this to around 2.5% by 2025.

questions.text: A mother brings her 4-year-old boy for a well-baby check-up. Upon examination the paediatrician diagnoses her son with hidden hunger. What is meant by the term hidden hunger?

choices.text: Child's diet is deficient in carbohydrates
Child is taking a diet that is deficient in essential amino acids
Child suffers from deficiency of omega 3 fatty acids

questions.solution:
Hidden hunger refers to micronutrient deficiency. It occurs when there is deficiency in intake or absorption of micronutrients like vitamins, iron, zinc, etc. 

The health effects of these deficiencies are less obvious or invisible and thus referred to as hidden hunger. The consequences of hidden hunger are seen in all ages.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct with regards to the estimation of poverty line?

choices.text: Per capita expenditure of Rs. 32 per day in urban areas
Per capita expenditure of Rs. 47 per day in rural areas
Daily calorie intake of 2100 calories in urban areas
Daily calorie intake of 2700 calories in rural areas

questions.solution:
An estimate of the poverty line is the expenditure required for a daily calorie intake of 2100 in urban areas and 2400 in rural areas, per person.

Income-based poverty line in India is per capita expenditure of Rs. 47 in urban areas and Rs. 32 in rural areas per day.

questions.text: Which of the following legislations does not offer social security for industrial workers?
questions.solution:
The Labour Charter Act does not offer social security for industrial workers.

Social security is the security that society furnishes through appropriate organization, against certain risks to which its members are exposed. These risks include sickness, maternity, old age and death.

Social security for industrial workers is given by:

  • Workmen’s Compensation Act
  • The Family Pension Scheme
  • Central Maternity Benefit Act
  • Employees’ State Insurance Act

Social security for civil servants is given by governments in the form of pension, gratuity, provident fund, etc. The Central Government Health Scheme provides security to employees of the Central Government.

Insurance schemes from the likes of Life Insurance Corporation of India, etc. have security schemes for the general public.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the global hunger index (GHI)?

choices.text: Percentage of  undernourished children under  5 years

questions.solution:
The infant mortality rate is not a component of the global hunger index.

The Global Hunger Index (GHI) has three dimensions. These dimensions are measured by indicators. 

Dimensions Indicators
Inadequate food supply Proportion of the population undernourished
Child mortality Under 5 mortality rate
Child undernutrition Wasting in children under 5 years
Stunting in children under 5 years

GHI score = (1/3 X standardized PUN) + (1/6 X standardised CWA) + (1/6 X standardised CST) + (1/3 X Standardised CM)

Where,

  • PUN is the proportion of the population that is undernourished
  • CWA is the prevalence of wasting in children under 5 years of age
  • CST is the prevalence of stunting in children under 5 years of age
  • CM is the proportion of children dying under the age of 5 years of age.

The result lies on a scale from 0 to 100, with 0 meaning no hunger and 100 being the worst score. The GHI is given by the International Food Policy Research Institute. In 2021, India's GHI was 27.5. It ranks 101 among 116 countries. In the 2022,India's GHI stands at 29.1, and India ranks 107th out of the 121 countries.
